item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: https://uws-blog.000webhostapp.com.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymised string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service Privacy Policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognise and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: vincent
item.content:encoded:
Hey, my name is Vincent, I am a 20 years old french student. I am currently studying Game Development in the University of the West of Scotland (UWS), and I wish you the welcome on my blog !  

  • About me

 For 8 years, computing and video games have taken an important part on my free time. First of all, I have started as a self-educated and I did many projects to discover deeper the computing field.

That's why, I decided to continue my studies in a first time in Electrical Engineering & Industrial Computing during 2 years, in order to discover fields like automations, electronic, embeded computing which were fields that interested myself.

Finaly, I decided to forward in the computing. Instead of chose directly a french engineering school, I have prefered to take this year in a foreign country, in order to improve my english which is a very important skill in this field and also in the profesional world.

Moreover, I believe that this experience to discover an other culture, way of work, lifestyle, and also one of the interesting specifities of computing (Game Development) is a great opportunity for me. Furthermore, I am sure about that this experience will help in my project of study after this year.

   

  • About the blog

This blog has been designed to cover various topics associated with ethical and professional aspects of the creative industries, In a first time, I will deal with subjects submitted during the Creative Technology Profesionalism course as creative industries, game design and related subjects. Moreover, in the future, I would like to publish other topics close to this fields !   Feel free to add me on your social account !

item.title: What makes a good portfolio or showreel in the creative industries ?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hello and welcome everyone to the first post of my Blog !

In this post, I will explain you in a first time the reasons of why a Porfolio/Showreel is required to work in the creative industries, and in the second part we will see how make a good one to promote your profile.

Let's start by the begining, what is a Portfolio ? "A portfolio is a living and changing collection of records that reflect your accomplishments, skills, experiences, and attributes. It highlights and showcases samples of some of your best work, along with life experiences, values and achievements." Source : Career center document

This document provide us an accurate definition of the Portfolio. Whereas a LinkedIn profile will promote your professional experience and diploma. A Portfolio is the showcase of your work (profesional or during your free time). Moreover, if you want to work in the creative industries you must have a decent Portfolio to impress your employer !

[caption id="attachment_528" align="alignright" width="1024"] A Portfolio with personality ![/caption]

If I would be an employer, seeking some profiles to work in my company, I would first of all check your LinkedIn profile and then I would expect a proof of your skills, and know more about you personality and your level.

In my opinion, a LinkedIn profile and a Portfolio are both complementary. They are incredible tools to promote your profile.

Speaking for myself, I believe that nowadays it is impossible to find a job in our industry without this 2 features, because you will be in contest with others profiles more interesting for the employer, even if you have the best diploma.

In order to convince you of my mind, I can give you a statistic proof :

"56 percent of all hiring managers are more impressed by a candidate’s online portfolio than any other personal branding tool. However, only 7 percent of job seekers have created an online portfolio." Source : 4 reasons you need an online portfolio

Is it not an incredible tool ? Furthermore, I can swear you that have a Portfolio will be more and more common in few years, it is actualy only used in some fields, and I can give you one as an example : The creative industries.

However, I am sure if I want to work in my country (France) and I haven't an enought decent Portfolio or a developed network, even if there are important studios (I think especially at EA, Ubisoft,...) I am sure I will stay without any job !

So how make a decent Portfolio ?

After studying the differents sources, I can give you a shortlist of advices :

  • Describe your old projects
  • Update it regulary, you should give information about your work in progress
  • Show your skills, you must impress the visitor of your website (I believe, that even if it is a complicated to do, add a showreel update showreel of your skills is the best thing you can do to enhance your profile)
  • Promote it, however nobody will come to check your profile !

To conclude this post, I will compare 2 Portfolio. The first one belongs to Adham Dannaway it is a perfect demonstration of what should be a Portfolio for me. For the second, I will share you a friend's Portfolio. I would like to show you that even if his website looks good, it is not a decent Portfolio to promote your profile, because there is nothing about his project or his experience  ! Could you guess he have a LinkedIn or he had a blog in the past ?

That's why it is important to keep his Portfolio update until he become useless and doesn't deserve you.

Hope you enjoyed this post, and as I told you about the importance of a Portfolio, you will find mine in a near future with my older project and this blog project !

Source:   Porfolio definition - from College of Charleston, Career center document Impact of a Portfolio for job seekers - from Levo ,  4 reasons you need an online portfolio Why a website is required - from Forbes, Why every job seeker should have a personal website and what it should include

item.title: Working in the creative industries: is freelancing the road to success ?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hello everyone and welcome for a new post this week,

This week I will study the question of freelancing, I will deal about pros & cons and give you my opinion about it. Is it a good choice of career ?

Basically we can say that freelancing is being a self-employe, that provide services to multiples customers. Be his own boss and work for the most part of the time alone, his a choice of career.

[caption id="attachment_523" align="aligncenter" width="500"] A choice of career[/caption]

As you may know, the freelancing in the EU is in good health, this numbers from the IPA are one more proof !

"Independent professionals in the EU grew from 6.2 million in 2004 to 8.9 million in 2013.The IPA's 2014 Agency Census revealed creative roles account for 41.8% of freelance jobs for member agencies." Source : CampaignLive - why creative industries embracing freelance economy

[caption id="attachment_524" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] What people believe about freelancing[/caption]
  • One of the most interesting advantage for freelancer, is as you work alone, you are only dependant of the customer's order. You  can manage as you want your time during the week.Moreover, you work for you because you are the boss here, you choose your contract with your customers.
  • The second major advantage is that you can choose your customers, it will able you to developp your network.
  • Furthermore due to the differentes orders you won't make the same thing all the time and you will permanently improve a variety of skills.
  • As you work alone you are more pay than in a traditional company (more fees)

With already this point of view with the advantages, you trust in a dream job, but there are also cons, like in all job.

Cons :

  • As you depend of your network's order, you must build and maitain a decent network in order to work during all the year and get your money, there is no job security it is very important to notice that !
  • You are not alone on the freelancer market. Remember the previous statistic, it will be a real contest between freelancer for interesting call, and there is many website to find orders (freelancer.co.uk , freelanceuk.com,  peopleperhour.com, etc)
  • You will probably work more than a traditionnal job because as a boss you must provide papers for the administration
  • Lonely...

My own point of view :

As you have maybe guess during this article I won't do a freelance, but it can be a good choice of career and the road to success in the creative industry.

It is pretty interesting thing to be in charge and manage his own time and skill to respond at customer's orders. I believe that it is a great experience, but until you have a decent network it is not a reliable situation.

So I will recomend to start a freelance when you get the network or when you have time and don't need a reliable situation (for your family for example).

I believe that it can be a great experience to do few years in freelancing before to comeback on the traditional work, because it will bring you another point of view of work than you colleague, and it is always interesting to have differents experiences.

How succeed as a freelancer  in the creative industry?

I think in one word we can define how succeed : Professionalism

If you provide a good work as the customer expect and you are aware about your network you will be an happy and successfull creative freelancer !

[caption id="attachment_522" align="aligncenter" width="580"] Road to success[/caption]

Source :

Statistics, from Campaign - Why creative industries embracing freelance economy

General informations, from CreativeSkillset - What's it like to work in the creative industries

Personal view, from FastoCreate - How to be a happy and successful creative freelancer or work with one

item.title: Intelectual Property rights and their importance in the creative industries
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hello everyone to my second post.

In this new post, I will in a first time deal about the Intelectual Property (IP) and then we will focusing more on IP rights in the creative industry.

[caption id="attachment_534" align="alignright" width="300"] It was your idea ?[/caption]

First of all, let's introduce a short definition of IP rights from the World Intellectual Property Organization  (WIPO) :

"Intellectual property refers to creations of the mind: inventions; literary and artistic works; and symbols, names and images used in commerce. Intellectual property is divided into two categories: Industrial property and Copyright"

In this quote, the WIPO define the IP to all kind of creations of the mind, it can be a right on a car model (industrial property) as well as a music (copyright), so it can be applied at a wide range of industry.

The aim of IP rights are like any other property right : They allow creators, or owners, of patents, trademarks or copyrighted works to prevent from a exploitation of the invention by a person or a company.

[caption id="attachment_535" align="aligncenter" width="480"] Youtube - Copyright claim[/caption]

This right is recognized  since 1883 and it has been established in order to give at the creator the benefit from their own work or investment in a creation. It able to the inventor to sell his rights, deliver licences (you pay for a service) or even to get royalties ! Whereas at the opposite there are also open source creations which will avoid this righst and provide this services free for you.

However, even if you are the author or creator of a new creation, you are not obviously the owner ! For example if I create a new ingenious game mechanic, if I work for a game development company, this company will be the owner of the right. So we can say that the IP rights able to prevent also company from their own employee.

Now I will deal more in details with the copyright since it will more interest us in the creative industry. The copyright covers creative fields as music, movies, art, web content, photography and others. This right is automatically obtained when you write: the copyright symbol, your name and the year on a original creation and it will protect your work in your country but also at the international. Moreover you can assert your right up to 70 years after you died (depending of the kind of creations), that's how if you are the son of Mickael Jackson you will  still receive money from his creation !

In my opinion, I believe that in the creative industry the copyright is a means to push the inovation. Creativity is what will able you to overcome the current limits and design a new concept. In this way, you will probably pass this limit and maybe create an awesome creation which will maybe become the new reference.

Even if sometimes the copyright of other will cost or block you in your project, you can always find a new way to do it. I remember an old version of Counter Strike (Source) in which Valve hadn't the rights on weapon's name yet. So they decided to "create" they own weapons which were just similar to the real weapons and create names (Maverick M4A1 Carabine instead of M4A1), smart ?

To conclude I will say that in the creative industry and more usually in all industry the Intelectual Property rights able to overcome the current limit. Even if it will be interesting I i think that a world with only open source invention without IP rights is not reliable for the invention. I believe that it will be the death of innovation because we will all adopt the same technology, so yes there is bad and good on IP rights but it is necessary to prevent the work provided and for the innovation !

Source : Global informations, from Wipo (World Intellectual Property Organization) - What is intelectual property Global information, from Innovation policy platform  IP and creative industry Copyright/Copyleft, from visionmobile blog  The open source trials hanging in the legal balance of copyright and copyleft Copyright in the UK, from the UK government  How copyright protects your work Music royalties, from  Johnsons Rambler blog  A deeper look at how much musicians make online

item.title: Does the concept of professionalism apply to the creative industries ?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hello everyone to this new post,

Today I will deal about Profesionalism, especially in the creative industry. If you have already work in a company, this word won't be strange for you, but for most of student they can't define Professionalism, so I want to show you on image what is the profesionalism :

[caption id="attachment_531" align="alignnone" width="1000"] This guy seems professional[/caption]

Personaly, the first word in mind when I pronounce "Professionalism" are : reliable, discipline, serving, competent. I think I will define a professional as a person who will bring what his customer desire, or even more, in the best way.

Why do I need to be professional ?

If you need to work in a important company, you can't go to work and want to be yourself, because once you are yourself you are  naturally unprofessional. In order to work in good terms and in the good way you need to adopt professional codes, which will depends of your field.

Identify a professional person [caption id="attachment_532" align="alignleft" width="300"] Professionalism Diagram[/caption]

I have found this image on one of my source, and I think it is a good diagram to define how you can begin a professional.

We can see that the professionalism is a melt beetween : behaviour, skills, knowledge.

Obviously if you want to provide a good work to your customers you shoud have a decent skillset and knowledge, depending on your field.

Although in my opinion I believe that behaviour is what will be differencing you as a professional and from your teammates. Because, theoretically you will have an equivalent level in technicals skills due to the fact that you are working on the same field. It will impact your communication and  your role wihin the group.

Professionalism in the creative industry [caption id="attachment_533" align="alignleft" width="400"] Robots in suits[/caption] First of all, to be a professional you must respect the codes of your field. Whereas in buisness, restoration or even in some school you must wear a kind of uniform to work. In the creative industry, I can  say that it is more creative, there is not a defined clothing code !

However for the work providden by developper the professionalism is a really important. When you are working in a company, you probably won't be alone on your project, that's why communication will be very important.

Althought, there is not only the oral communication, as a developper your codes must be first of all reliable and understandable by any others developpers. They should be able to understand your codes, mainly because a computing project is updated permanently and when someone would like to help you or, even better fill your work because you left the company, in order to continue the development.

As well as you must respect a standard developping method to be understandable by anyone and communicate around your project. I believe that the third rules which will make you a professional is to respect the deadlines and to keep update of important news in your fields.

For example, as a professional I should return this blog today with this post !

Source : Global informations, from ccSkills - Being a creative professional Global informations, from the context of things's Blog - Professionalism in the workplace Ethic, from ethical systems - Professionalsim and ethics Tips to become a professional, from tech republic's Blog - 10 things that define a true professional

item.title: Technical Report : Impact of social, casual and mobile games in the evolving games
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
As an other assessment for this module, I have also study more in details a subject of the creative industry in order to write a complete technical report around it.

 

You can find my Technical Report dealing about the Impact of social, casual and mobile game in the evolving games industry right there
